column6: description
Top-level subnational administrative area (e.g. a governorate in Syria).
Second-level subnational administrative area (e.g. a subdivision in Bangladesh).
Third-level subnational administrative area (e.g. a subdistrict in Afghanistan).
Fourth-level subnational administrative area (e.g. a barangay in the Philippines).
Fifth-level subnational administrative area (e.g. a ward of a city).
Country (often left implied in a dataset). Also sometimes known as admin level 0.
Geodetic geometry information (points, lines, shapes). Use for latitude and longitude, as well as bounds information.
Any general location, such as a village, camp, or clinic.

A broad, supra- or cross-national geographical region (e.g. Sahel, Horn of Africa, Central Asia, Caribbean). Not to be confused with "region" used as the name of a subnational area (#adm1) in some countries.
Number of people or households affected by an emergency. Subset of #population; superset of #inneed.
General (non-numeric) information about a person or group meant to benefit from aid activities, e.g. "lactating women".
Number of people or households in need of humanitarian assistance. Subset of #affected; superset of #targeted.
General population number for an area or location, regardless of their specific humanitarian needs.
Number of people or households reached with humanitarian assistance. Subset of #targeted.
Descriptive information, such as name, identifier, or traits, for a single respondee (person, household, etc.) in survey-style data.
Number of people or households targeted for humanitarian assistance. Subset of #inneed; superset of #reached.
Accessiblity and constraints on access to a market, distribution point, facility, etc.
A programme, project, or other activity. This hashtag applies to all levels; use the attributes +activity, +project, or +programme to distinguish different hierarchical levels.
The response capacity of the entity being described (e.g. "25 beds").
Contact information for the subject of a data record (e.g. an activity).
The frequency with which something occurs.
A general hashtag for an indicator being tracked. See also #output, #capacity, #need, #impact, #severity, #affected, #inneed, #targeted, and #reached for more-specific indicator-related hashtags.
Physical things provided, stored, shipped, available, used, etc.
A(n) (unfulfilled) need for an affected person, household, group, or population.
Information that affects humanitarian operations, such as a restriction on movement or road closure.

An organisation contributing to a humanitarian emergency response, e.g. a local government, community-based organisation, NGO, agency, donor, or law-enforcement or military unit. Use #group for organisations that are not part of the emergency response (e.g. a paramilitary group).
An output indicator (e.g. "number of water-purification kits distributed"). A more-specific alternative to #indicator, especially for 3W-style activity reports.
A humanitarian cluster or sector.
A service used or needed by an affected person, household, group, or population.
A humanitarian subsector.
The detailed method of delivering aid (e.g. smartcard vs mobile transfer). More specific than #modality.
Name or ISO 4217 currency code for all financial #value cells in the row (e.g. "EUR"). Typically used together with #value in financial or cash data.
The means by which an aid activity is accomplished. For cash transfers, values might include "cash", "vouchers", "in-kind", etc. May also be used for other types of modalities in other contexts.
A monetary value, such as the price of goods in a market, a project budget, or the amount of cash transferred to beneficiaries. May be used together with #currency in financial or cash data.
The cause of an event, crisis, etc.
A humanitarian emergency.
An individual event or incident within a crisis/emergency, such as a (localised) flood, bridge collapse, or conflict.

A non-humanitarian group (of any type) related to humanitarian crisis (e.g., a paramilitary group) Use #org instead for a humanitarian organisation such as an NGO, contributing to the humanitarian response.
The impact of a crisis on a group or other entity.
Severity of the crisis or event.
Date related to the data in the record applies. Preferred format is ISO 8610 (e.g. "2015-06-01", "2015-Q1", etc.)
Long description for a data record.
Metadata about a row.
Project/activity status description (such as "planned", "active", "canceled", or "complete").
